poem:
Title: On the Outskirts of a Blind Date

Best table, by
the window's gaze -
a quiet unfolding,
hands clasping hellos.

We caught reflections -
war-stamped fathers, the
pull of progeny,
the spectral dance of
Labour's politics.

He, in Lycra, carved
from tech's cold matrix;
I, in sea-salt, inked
with life's rich lexicon.

Us, in the firm hold of hopes,
nursing the alluring 
possibility.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Blind date: ‘She’s had an illustrious writing career, but it felt like a conversation between equals’ Deborah on Mike What were you hoping for?A possibility – the most alluring word I know. First impressions?Nice-looking, firm handshake. He’d got us the best table, by the window. What did you talk about?Our pasts, our fathers’ service in the war, the Labour party, our children, biking, sea swimming (which we both love, but I suspect he’s more of a Lycra sporty person than me). Some techy stuff – he’s far more involved in that". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.

What did you talk about?Our pasts, our fathers’ service in the war, the Labour party, our children, biking, sea swimming (which we both love, but I suspect he’s more of a Lycra sporty person than me).
